mc_pro_critic_reviews.summary: Even when Disconnect follows the path we expect it to follow, it does so in a way that keeps us intensely engaged. There wasn't a moment during this movie when I thought about anything other than this movie.

The film ominously conveys a world of too much information but too little communication, where people have become slaves to glowing hand-held devices that were designed to make life easier but have made it busier and more complicated.

Disconnect is naturally gripping. Using unforgiving closeups, Rubin pokes into unexpected corners— not least the different ways in which men and women respond to calamity — and never forces his story's social-media scares to improbable heights.
The film builds to a three-pronged tumultuous climax, shot in slow motion that could have been overwrought but somehow isn’t.
Characters are richly drawn and relatable, though at times stories teeter on melodrama. The overall effect, however, is powerful.
Disconnect is by turns frustrating and fascinating.
Bateman, in a rare dramatic role, is just tremendous, finding depths of emotion where they're least expected. Disconnect works they same way. Even when it trips on its ambitions, it hits home.
Despite occasional flaws, Disconnect is filled with fine performances, informed by an often sophisticated script and directed with passion.
It’s a blunt instrument of a movie, and often melodramatic. But it sometimes moves and often hits its target square on the nose.
As cautionary tales go, Disconnect is a pretty good one, but it’s not really a whole lot more than that.

The structure is sheer contrivance — three narratives intricately interlocked — while the plot amounts to a convenience store of variably credible, or borderline incredible, strands. Yet the film is impressive all the same.
If this strikes you as vaguely familiar, you’re right: Disconnect is a computer “Crash.”
Soulful though the film is, melodrama gradually sneaks in, and then it takes over.

Disconnect is an Eleanor Rigby movie. Look at all the lonely people. A "Crash" for the Internet age, Alex Henry Rubin's topical opus swoops down like an alien spaceship to investigate a disparate group of Earthlings living in close proximity in the suburbs of New York City.
Disconnect is far from a bad movie. It’s just better at melodrama than drama.

The film's message -- about how the Internet is sabotaging our real-life relationships -- doesn't resonate with absolute clarity, but Disconnect does a much more effective job than anyone could hope to do in 140 characters or less.
The fine cast pushes beyond the script’s limits, even if some, like Hope Davis as Ben’s mom, are mostly wasted.
Alas, the flick can't resist overheating. Paradoxically, when people finally do jump in their cars, curl their fists and grab their guns, we wish they'd retreat to the safety of their monitors.
Disconnect might play better a decade from now, when it's more clearly a compendium of contemporary fears rather than some dire expression of them.
Well-meaning but dated and frequently risible issue-drama.
Only Andrea Riseborough comes close to rising above it all, and even she’s undone by what may be the crassest climactic slo-mo montage ever. The lucky will have logged off by that point.
And come on, guys: There’s nothing cinematic about Googling.
Fails not so much because of its occasional self-seriousness or didacticism than it does from a scattered plot that makes the story's overriding theme or message difficult to grasp.

mc_user_reviews.text: With great performances and a story that not only works as a lesson about the technological world we live in, but also works as a riveting piece of film making.  This is one of my favorite films of the year so far. A
This movie was brilliant. The concept was imaginative and thoughtful and the acting wonderful. I've rarely cared about characters so much. It's the best movie I've seen this year.

Anybody remember the 2010 movie 'Trust'? Well, this is another version consisting of many different and connected stories. Very nicely written script about cyber crimes. This kind of movie is much needed in the present world because the nuisance growing rapidly everywhere. You would get many similar movies to this like 'Identity Thief' etc., but not serious as the reality. So this movie is one of the kind that the modern world had seen with the concept of existing online culture.
I looooved this. Great cast. I liked the overlap of the different story lines. A friend told me about it. I knew nothing about it and was pleasantly surprised.

Boring rubbish from start to finish. Can't believe anybody would think this says anything about www or how they can see anything in this film that we don't all already know. Shallow, banal and worthless.

I just saw Disconnect on HBO, and I'm very surprised that so many critics missed the boat on this film, which is so compelling.  The plot sucks you in right from the start, and the actors give excellent performances, making you really care about these characters.  The message is there about the negative impact of the Internet, computers, and cell phones on all our lives, but it is blended into the suspense in the narrative, which reflects so much of what modern life is like, how technology can disconnect from each other.
A gripping, heavy, thought-provoking, story, told in a believable fashion.  Script, acting and score was top notch.  Gives parents food for thought in this connected age.
I really liked this movie! it was really interesting  I liked the stories and how they were putted together  the acting was great  especially bateman  I recommend it to all.

This movie is brilliant. Directed in a style similar to Crash, Disconnect tells the stories of numerous people trying to cope with the consequences of life on the web. A compelling plot that represents a generation.
This Movie really makes you think about all the things that happens to people everyday, and how all kinds of problems can appear by just doing click on something... A Thriller!
good movies the story is very intense kinda remind me of babel

Surprise Surprise! Never thought a film about human connections emerging as a result of mistakes committed online could be of such high standards. its heart warming, provocative, unbiased and emotional. It works so well specially because it doesn't get side tracked, even though the premise allows for such deviations. The writing is taut and it is aptly supported by some brilliant background score and camerawork

Disconnect tell 3 stories of people trying to cope with life all of which turn to the internet. Really interesting and new concept the three stories are all very different from each other all reaching to different problems from cyber bullying to internet fraud, definately worth watching
An authentic and important movie with stories that kinda interconnect about how technology can affect our lives in directions that we did not see coming.
An amazing Drama that made me cry, Guys do not cry. It's impossible. This Movie amazed me and touched me on all the right places. The incredible Acting is just the cherry on the beautiful Cake.
